claim: Aretha Franklin could have voted for a president when her second child was born.

supporting.text: Aretha Franklin was born in 1942, making her 18 years old in 1960, the year her second child was born, which is the legal voting age in the U.S.

attacks.text: Aretha Franklin was born in 1942, making her 18 years old in 1960, the year her second child was born, which is the legal voting age in the U.S.
The legal voting age in the U.S. was 21 until 1971, when the 26th Amendment lowered it to 18. In 1960, Aretha Franklin would not have been eligible to vote.
Some states had already lowered the voting age to 18 before the 26th Amendment, so Aretha Franklin might have been eligible to vote in certain states in 1960.
There is no evidence that Aretha Franklin lived in a state that had lowered the voting age to 18 before the 26th Amendment, making it unlikely she could vote in 1960.

supporting.text: The 1960 U.S. presidential election occurred on November 8, 1960, and Franklin was of legal voting age by that time.

attacks.text: The 1960 U.S. presidential election occurred on November 8, 1960, and Franklin was of legal voting age by that time.
Aretha Franklin's second child was born in 1970, not during the 1960 election cycle.
Franklin could have voted in the 1968 presidential election, which was still before her second child was born.
There is no public record confirming whether Franklin actually voted in any presidential election.

supporting.text: There were no legal barriers preventing Franklin from voting in 1960, as she was a U.S. citizen and met all eligibility requirements.

attacks.text: There were no legal barriers preventing Franklin from voting in 1960, as she was a U.S. citizen and met all eligibility requirements.
Though legally eligible, Franklin may have faced practical barriers such as voter suppression tactics prevalent in some areas during the 1960s.
Franklin was a public figure with resources and connections that likely mitigated common voter suppression barriers.
The claim assumes Franklin was registered to vote in 1960, but no records confirm her registration status at that time.
Given Franklin's later civic engagement, it's reasonable to infer she was registered to vote during her prime years.

supporting.text: Franklin's second child was born in 1960, and she could have voted in the presidential election that same year, as the election occurred after her birthday.

attacks.text: Franklin's second child was born in 1960, and she could have voted in the presidential election that same year, as the election occurred after her birthday.
Franklin may not have been registered to vote in 1960, which would have prevented her from voting in the presidential election.
Voter registration records from 1960 are incomplete, making it difficult to confirm whether Franklin was registered or not.
Franklin may have been traveling or otherwise occupied on election day, preventing her from voting despite being eligible.
There is no documented evidence that Franklin was unavailable to vote on election day in 1960.
